messages.message:
Hi team, had a call with a commercial customer we are looking to start a POC with, and they raised a fair concern about security I hadn't heard before.

_"What protections does AI Hub have in place to stop anyone in the workspace downloading data to their personal machine? We might be okay without it for the POC, but we will not sign off the use of this software without restrictions in place for normal usage."_ 

Their concern is around the 'download as CSV/Excel' button in an apps Human Review and the corresponding API calls, which anyone who is part of a workspace can currently do. Presumably users are not able to download docs from the configuration stage of a Build project either (although I'm not sure whether hacking around the APIs you could do this)? My assumption is that this (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-823?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiYTJjYTNhYzJhZWI1NGIyNzhkNmU0N2JkZDhlYzFlOTciLCJwIjoiaiJ9) feature may solve this, but I will need confirmation given their strict requirements. When is this due to be GA?

cc @Nico @Tom @hannah

i don’t think the groups feature will cover this

cc @andy to confirm
There currently are no implementations to block the CSV export option, all users have access to it.
@Tom @Nico this will be a major blocker to this deal unless we can find a solution to this or prioritise it as a roadmap item

we can add a block to that feature, but I am weary that our current permissions approach isn’t granular enough to control it across all clients. I’m not familiar with how groups operate but perhaps we could enable a group permission/setting to block the exporting of data?
It makes sense to me to have that as an option that managers could toggle for reviewers - either to have the ability to export data + call via API or not

Groups by itself would not address this - it doesn't add new permissions, just a way to bulk assign existing permissions. This quarter we're going to start work on user roles to be able to have more granular permissions. This sounds like something that could be solved by introducing a "reviewer" role that does not have permission to download. This is probably a quarter out, we haven't started scoping it yet.
Is there a way for the end customer to block downloads in the browser? locally

The initiative ticket to track would be this one: https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-2388. I'll add this to the list of granular permissions to consider. I heard a similar request earlier today about not letting all users in Build write code.

@Tom I think there are tools for this, though I'm not an expert in it. Things like https://www.interguardsoftware.com/file-activity-monitoring-software/ & https://www.broadcom.com/products/cybersecurity/information-protection/data-loss-prevention could be relevant.
